p: Studies of intravenous drug users (IDU) estimated that they inject themselves around ~700 (300–1,800) times a year [ 125, 126, 127, 128, 129, 130, 131]. In Western IDUs, explosive HIV-1 spread happened more commonly in the 1980s (with prevalence attaining 15%–70%), when they shared needles more frequently and needle exchange programs, methadone, and other harm reduction interventions were still incipient or non-existent [ 125, 132, 133, 134, 135, 136]. For IDUs observed at the start, or in early stages, of these interventions the average frequency of needle sharing (counting all individuals including non-sharers) was normally in the range 60–245 needle sharing events per year (and much higher counting sharers only) [ 125, 131, 132, 133, 137].
